questions.text:
![](/content/media/uveitis-1-3.webp)

![](/content/media/uveitis-1-4.webp)

The patient's OCT is shown above. What abnormalities do you visualize in the patient's OCT image?

answers.answerText: C. Acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy
answers.explanation:
APMPPE is an acquired inflammatory uveitis and an uncommon White Dot Syndrome. It is characterized by hyperreflectivity from the outer plexiform layer to the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) with normal retinal thickness. Some patients may have subretinal fluid or intraretinal cysts. The absence of the ellipsoid zone (EZ) may also indicate foveal involvement and correlate with the loss of visual acuity. Anterior uveitis can be present, as well as mild vitritis.

References

​Lim LL, Watzke RC, Lauer AK, Smith JR. Ocular coherence tomography in acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy. Clin Exp Ophthalmol. 2006 Nov;34(8):810–2.

​Onal S, Tugal-Tutkun I, Neri P, P Herbort C. Optical coherence tomography imaging in uveitis. Int Ophthalmol. 2014 Apr;34(2):401–35.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: If this is her first presentation, what other systemic conditions should this patient be worked up for?

answers.explanation: CNS vasculitis can be associated with APMPPE, which all patients with a new diagnosis of APMPPE should be investigated for. Other CNS disorders that are sometimes associated include optic neuritis, peripheral vestibular disorders, meningoencephalitis, seizures, venous sinus thrombosis, intracerebral hemorrhage, and transient ischemic attacks.

title: Case 1
description: 31F presenting with a 1 week history of bilateral blurred vision
patientPresentation:
**Contributors:** Dr. John Liu, Dr. Irfan Kherani, Dr. Chloe Gottlieb

A 31-year-old female presents with a 1-week history of sudden, painless, bilateral blurred vision with central scotomas, worse in her right eye. Two weeks prior, she experienced flu-like symptoms, which have now resolved. On fundus exam, there are creamy grey-white placoid lesions at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) in the posterior pole.
